1: HANDLE = UcsHandle(…
2: SERVER_POOL = ComputePool(…
3: HANDLE.add_mo(SERVER_POOL)
4: SERVER = ComputePooledSlot(…
5: SP_TEMPLATE = LsRequirement(…
6: commit
7: logout

https://vwannabe.com/2017/01/31/ucs-b-series-configuration-using-the-ucs-sdk-and-python/

1. UCSHandle (user interface point for any UCS)
2. ComputePool (Create a Server Pool)
3. add_mo (add a managed object to the UCSHandle commit buffer) - for - looping
4. ComputePooledSlot (Create a Server Pool Slot)
5. LSRequirement (Create Service Profile Template)
6. commit (commits the buffer to the server)
7. logout (disconnect from the server referenced by the UCShandle)

1. UcsHandle

4. ComputePooledSlot
5. LsRequeriment
6. commit
7. logout

discussion.content:
import intersight_auth

# Set the API key ID and secret key obtained from the Intersight UI
api_key_id = 'YOUR_API_KEY_ID'
api_key_secret = 'YOUR_API_SECRET_KEY'

# Create an Intersight API authentication object
auth = intersight_auth.InterSightAuth(api_key_id, api_key_secret)

# Make an API request using the authenticated session
import requests
url = 'https://intersight.com/api/v1/compute/PhysicalSummaries'
response = requests.get(url, auth=auth)

# Print the response content
print(response.content)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Correct answers: A & B

Sources:
https://blog.wimwauters.com/networkprogrammability/2020-06-08_guestshell_onbox/
https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/on-box-python-for-devices

Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct:
There are three main advantages for Python scripts running on the device itself rather than externally.
- Scale, security, autonomy.
https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/on-box-python-for-devices

choices.D: It supports Qt for graphical interfaces and dashboards.
choices.B: It is a Python interpreter installed inside the guest shell.
choices.C: It enables execution of XML scripts on a Cisco IOS XE router or switch.
choices.E: It has access to Cisco IOS XE web UI through a controller.
choices.A: It has direct access to Cisco IOS XE CLI commands.
